Lesson 2: Establishing Program Goals and Outcomes

“We must realize— and act on the realization — that if we try to focus on everything, we focus on nothing.”

John Doerr

Once you have a mission statement that communicates where you want to go, it’s vital to map out how you are going to get there. Establishing goals and desired outcomes is a powerful way to build and maintain a program of quality.

Instructions: Select each dropdown below to learn more about some of the most important benefits of using goals:

  • Meaning and Purpose

    Goals drive meaning. They give purpose to your everyday work and help create an effective and successful culture.

  • Prioritization

    Goals help you prioritize what to work on and when. Running a program requires many tasks and responsibilities. Being able to evaluate all of these calls for attention is much easier when you can ask, “How does this work towards my goals?”

  • Benchmarks

    Goals give benchmarks to continually evaluate your progress

Image by 8photo under Freepik

An Intentional Process

Goal-setting is an intentional process that requires thought and attention to your mission. Large, vague goals can help you begin the process of goal-setting, but they need to be broken down into smaller, more tangible objectives that can be measured. Moreover, having an explicit process for setting goals is crucial for cultivating an environment of collaboration, accountability, and success in your program.

Objectives and Key Results

One popular goal-setting framework used to define measurable goals and monitor their outcomes is objectives and key results (OKRs). Many successful individuals, teams, and organizations, such as Google and U2’s Bono, use OKRs to drive results. Now watch this video featuring John Doerr, author of Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs as he explains the benefits and process for creating OKRs.

Brainstorm

Take out a clean sheet of paper and start recording any thoughts you have for goals you’d like to set. This exercise is not meant to be defined. Dream big, keep the pencil on the page, and let the ideas flow freely without judgment. We will refine these ideas later. Right now, give yourself the freedom to write continuously for at least five minutes.

Once you’ve finished your brainstorming, read through what you wrote and choose one idea that stands out.

“If the heart doesn’t find a perfect rhyme with the head, then your passion means nothing. The OKR framework cultivates the madness, the chemistry contained inside it. It gives us an environment for risk, for trust, where failing is not a fireable offense. And when you have that sort of structure and environment and the right people, magic is around the corner.”

Bono

According to Doerr, most people either don’t set goals well or don’t set them at all, leading their work to lack a sense of purpose. Combining ambition with passion and purpose is the clearest path to developing compelling sense goals. Therefore, to begin an effective goal-setting process, we must answer three big questions.

Instructions: Select each tab to learn about the three big questions we must answer.

  • Why?
  • What?
  • How?

Why?

What’s your purpose? Why are your goals important? How do they align with your values and mission?

What?

What do you want to accomplish? What is your objective? Be sure that it’s:

  • Significant
  • Concrete
  • Action-Oriented
  • Inspiring

How?

What are the key results and how do you get them done? Good key results are:

  • Specific & Time Bound
  • Aggressive, yet Realistic
  • Measurable & Verifiable

Use the OKR Participant Handout to fully explain one of your goals on paper. Once you’ve finished, share and reflect below:

Goal Setting Form

What statement is most applicable to your goal and key results?

Goal setting can be challenging! Wherever you are in the process, it’s always helpful to take a break and return to your goals later to gain deeper perspective and insight. Talking with a colleague or mentor can shed additional light on what you are trying to achieve and how you can do it

What stakeholders will have to be involved to reach your key result? Check all the apply:

Great job thinking through who needs to be involved now to help you plan for success.

What factors are most likely to stand in your way of achieving your goal? Check all that apply.

Knowing what's holding you back is an important step in your planning process. If you can anticipate hurdles, you can prepare for them by troubleshooting sooner rather than later.

Accountability is an important part of succeeding at achieving your goals. What will you do in order to hold yourself accountable? Check all that apply.

Sharing your goal with others brings your goals to light, making them more visible and creating a natural network of accountability. Be sure to think through the best person to share your goal with, how you’ll share it and when.
